commentBody: Here is your daily reminder to vote for the Griddies! (Puzzle of the year 2024, awarded in 2025). This first round of voting ends Jan 24. Head over to Eric Hougland’s at the link below, where your ballot awaits. It’s easy! No standing in line! You’ll have to supply your own “I voted” sticker, though. You’ll be able to vote for up to 5 puzzles in each category. The ballot has descriptions and dates so you can look puzzles up in the archives to refresh your memory. https://form.jotform.com/243358842724059
Early week puzzles getting tougher

Sam thinks that RVER is a strange designation for someone who owns and drives a recreational vehicle, but as a former RVER myself, I'll say that unlike ALER, NLER, NFLER and all those other sports league terms, this one is in actual, real life use. Here's one site on the first page of hits for the Google search for RVER: https://thewanderingrver.com/ And another: https://rverjobexchange.com/ And one more for good luck: https://americanrver.com/ Our personal experience with RVing was in the earliest years of the century, with our biggest adventure a cross-country trip of about three weeks in 2002. Lots of fun, but storing the RV was a problem, and we got rid of it shortly thereafter. Thinking about getting another one some day!
Checked over all my answers three times, but still one square is amiss :(

This Tuesday was chock full of nuggets of all sorts.  Music of various stripes was present throughout: LUISFONSI, MELC, WHAM(minus the !), and Janis Joplin (and therefore by inference Kris Kristofferson) via Me and Bobby MCGEE.  DC cartoon characters like HAL Jordan and LEX Luthor stood shoulder to shoulder with mythological/religious figures like VISHNU and Selene.  Neologisms like WMD, RVER, and (the new to me) BRODOWN abounded, and a veritable menagerie of SCAVENGERS lurked within the long acrosses.  It was a spicy salmagundi for a Tuesday.

As an aside, I was pleased to get WHAM, not having thought of them in several decades.

An observation on scavengers. Many years ago while travelling in Africa, I was informed that, if you saw a group of lions eating some prey being hungrily watched by hyenas, then the is good chance that it was the hyenas that in fact did the hunting and were then chased off by he lions.

So: one Spice Girl reference is a blip. Two is a pattern. Throw in WHAM and you have a deliberate attempt at torture against the Geneva convention.

Also, is it my imagination or did we just have Michael CERA and MAO clued exactly the same way in recent puzzles? Thought the editors would mix it up a bit.

Finally, a funny bit of trivia, CLEAVE is a word that can mean it’s opposite.

Nothing really against this puzzle by the way although it was a bit trivial proper noun heavy for a Tuesday.
MELC? Really?

Spent over half my time trying to find the single square that was wrong, which would up being the cross of 1A and 3D. Look, I’m not saying ScARF is the only valid dictionary word, and as a non-military guy, I know that all the things I imagined “cCO” stood for were probably wrong ([Chief/Central/etc] Commanding Officer) compared to the more well known NCO. All I’m saying is that I will never think of the word “SNARF” in any context but the Thundercats.

Not sure I’ve ever heard the word SNARF except for the name of Lion-O’s sidekick bud on Thundercats. 

Another relatively difficult puzzle IMO -  but fun was had, to be sure. 

Thanks for the challenge, Dan Caprera!

I just went on a SCAVENGER HUNT for a wrong letter - finally figured out I had ScARF for 1A. *sigh* It would have been a PB if not for that one wrong letter. Such is life. Enjoyed all of the music references (my 14 year old loves Last Christmas). My high school and college both had bagpipers, so KILT also stirred fond memories. 

I enjoyed this one, Dan, so thank you.

Hmm 🤔 I just saw MAO, OMELETTE, CERA and KOI within a week. Why does this happen (seriously)?

I only know Posh (because of her hubby) and Mel B. Other Spice Girls are a mystery. As of today I can name one song: 2 BECOME 1. Did I miss much?

Speaking of missing, I sure do miss George Michael of WHAM. He was a crush during my early teen years. I didn’t care that he’d never be interested in me, lol.

I’m looking forward to Carnival again this year. The one in my town is said to be the best in Portugal. It’s so much fun 🤩 💃🏾 🎉. OHYOUHAVENOIDEA about the goings on! Then, we sober up and get serious with LENT.

Bom terça-feira!

Snarf got me…

But check out Snarfburger in Boulder, CO.  

As it’s cold out, I’ll take a Scarfburger.
Anybody else automatically sit up straighter when solving 19-Down?

Another Toughened Up Tuesday that required some brain power to solve. As Pani mentions below, a number of deja vu clue/fill combos. I was a bit surprised at how frequently KOI has turned up through the years, and in honor of its appearance today, here's an unlocked link to a story in the Times about how a couple in Altadena rescued their KOI after fire passed through their neighborhood. https://nytimes.com/2025/01/20/realestate/los-angeles-wildfires-koi-rescue.html?unlocked_article_code=1.q04.1DVl.ksrM3I1-9ilE&smid=url-share

I just assumed “Canine welcomes”  were LICKS!!   I was stuck for the longest time in the lower left because I didn’t know the Spice Girls song “2 BECOME 1.”  Once I looked it up, I immediately realized the correct answer was BARKS!  🤦🏼‍♀️

This was fun today! Like most have commented, I wasn’t familiar with SNARF but it worked!

Tough Tuesday! I changed Bobby McGee to Bobby Magee when I realized the C made it MELC, which made no sense to me as a name. I knew it was McGee but talked myself into the change for the sake of the Spice Girl. 

Grr. 

I did enjoy the scavenger hunt though!
Rough one for those of us with gaps in our Spice Girls and Joplin knowledge

AH, YOU HAVE NO IDEA what a SCAVENGER HUNT I've been on, STALKing a sneaky typo.  I don't mean to be KOI, but OMELETTE you guess how close I've come to blowing my LID going OVER it, again and again.  I keep thinking "ICIER!" but no, that fill is correct, and I'm BARKing up the wrong tree.

ANYHOw (not fond of HOO—guess I'm just not WOK enough), it's a wonderful puzzle, and the hidden letter has LENT a certain HEROic essence to MAO quest, but I ZINC I've paid my DUES now, and I'm going to just say que CERA, CERA. and go to bed.  

You've given us a lovely puzzle, Dan Caprera.  Thank you very much!

"Snarf?" Is that really a real word?

In terms of scavengers, I had never heard that lions scavenge about 40% of their meals, but I figure it must be leftovers from other lions.
Solid Hal Jordan and also my favorite Spice Girls song. It’s sweet.

So apparently, according to repeated references in the NYT, Michael Cera was the lead actor in the Barbie movie.  Curious. :)

This was a reasonable puzzle.  I had, shockingly, quibbles.  A wok is hardly a stir fry "accessory" - it's the whole enchilada.  I really wish Union Requirements could have remained "I Dos" because at least that would have been a little clever.  "Anyhoo" is a weak answer.  Does a T-shirt really constitute "work out apparel"?  Sigh, I guess.  I also didn't much like the theme or its execution.  From the Wordplay column it seems the constructor admits to straight up Googling to create it, which tracks I suppose.


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
At last my Spice Girls knowledge pays off!

Nishikigoi has the word “koi” in it…..
(Goi = Koi: Japanese language rules makes the “k”  become a “g” but it’s the same word with the same kanji character)

So…this is technically not allowed as a clue. 

Just saying….

I would snark about SNARF, but it’s already been beaten to death. (Watch out, here comes a hyena!) And can we also agree on a strict limit of one Spice Girls reference per puzzle? 

In other nits, I found it odd to see two appearances of MAO (via Andy Warhol’s paintings) in two days. Must be something in the air.
Apart from the well deserved uproar for "SNARF", I'd like to pour scorn on "BRODOWN". That's simply not a thing.
Do people really use the word "snarf"?  I have never heard it or seen it outside the NYT crossword.
Can anyone else not see the circles easily? Luckily they didn’t matter for the solve, but it would be nice to have them more visible.

A bit on the tough side for a Tuesday but just made for a nice workout. Tumbling to the trick was a big help in a couple of places and that's always a nice touch. A couple of complete unknowns in the answers but that's not uncommon and I managed to work them out.

And, of course my puzzle find today. A Wednesday from June 8, 2005 by Richard Chisolm. Three theme answers in that one that would often be appropriate for my solving experience: 

WILDGOOSECHASE
SCAVENGERHUNT
TRIVIALPURSUIT

And... way off topic, but an odd weather report. Thought we might actually get some snow here today, and I guess it's still possible but... looks like it's a lot more likely - south of here. Hmmm.. 

I'll shut up now. 

...
Please get with the times. Something like Discord is far more popular and utile than Zoom is for such purposes.

MAO & CERA both appeared very recently (were they both yesterday?) with the same clues - what am I paying my editors for?!
This was a nice Tuesday solve for me, only a few references I had to guess - HAL, RVER, BRODOWN, HERO et al. Strangely I was totally on board with SNARF, it's a nice not-so-common synonym of snaffle :)
Many thanks Mr Caprera!

SNARF leading into a puzzle about scavenging seemed very appropriate. 

I'm glad Dan did a little research and included the LION as a scavenger.  They have great PR and are a little embarrassed by that fact, but it's time to end the shame.

Well I knew SNARF! I don't know why. Enjoyable today.
The crossers were exceptionally helpful for me today. I had only 2 to look up - LOUIS FONZI and HAL; fortunately the other proper names revealed themselves.
 Some previously mysterious solutions have appeared before, as others have mentioned, also for me BAIL, COOTIE, HERO, PLOWS not ploughs. 
Let's hope WMD remain a distant memory.

Goodness, that was an interesting Tuesday. A little chewier than of late but full of interesting fill. The SCAVENGER theme was fun while being Tuesday do-able.
Some of the answers were a little meh perhaps; SNARF, BRODOWN. But overall a good grid I thought.

Sam, round here we call RV-ERS Grockles; tourists who are incapable of driving their large vehicles down our narrow, twisty lanes and clearly don’t know how to use reverse gear. The times we’ve had to go out and literally take over and reverse their RV’s for them is ridiculous. We brace ourselves for general idiocy every Summer.
interesting and a little unpredictable for a tuesday--fun!
scarf / snarf kept me puzzled forever. did anyone know NCO vs CCO off the top of their head? it’s not really a well known abbreviation, I don’t think

Count me as someone who thought this was a bit hard for a Tuesday, although I still landed a couple of minutes below my average.

Here's a question for you: when someone uses the jocular word  that is pronounced ANYHOO do they intend the last syllable to be HOO or WHO? I don't think I've ever seen it in print before, but in my book it falls within the category of initially clever but overdone ages ago, like "Happy belated birthday".

Cool moment: I tried to guess the revealer after leaving it empty, couldn’t think of what the circled animals had in common, and as I sat in blankness, my eyes rested on OH YOU HAVE NO IDEA and it felt like the puzzle was saying “Gotcha!”  Never had that happen before! 

Also – and I liked this – the puzzle felt like an echo chamber.  BARKS echoing yesterday’s dog puzzle. ASP, EWE, DOE, KOI, and even NOAH echoing the faunal theme.  And TARTAR echoing the theme by doubling up on a notorious scavenger when read backward.

By the way, this theme uses 61 squares, and that’s a tough build.  Bravo, Dan!

I also liked STALK crossing the LION answer.  I laughed when the [Playground pathogen] turned out to be COOTIE.  I smiled at the loveliness of CLEAVE and zippiness of WHAM.  And what a lovely TIL from Dan’s notes that 40 percent of a lion’s diet comes from scavenging. Huh!

Lingering over the completed grid for a few moments, letting the brain scavenge for connections – well, for me, that often doubles the pleasure of the solve itself.  It certainly did today. Thank you so much, Dan, for a splendid outing.

Too sleepy and chilly this morning,
so not really in the mood to comment,

but

1) great puzzle, and 

2) seriously? SNARF is getting everyone
     all hot and bothered? 

SNARF? We see that allll the time!
And I hear it used…bunches!

And crossing NCO is almost like crossing Oreo!

Honestly feel like I’m being punked.
Like tomorrow there’ll be an uproar
over Erie or Eno.

Is it upside-down day..?

Took 25% longer than average.

Not heard of LUISFONSI,the Greek Titan Selene, or BRODOWN (originally guessed BROtOWN).
MELC seemed suspect, but I vaguely remember two Spice Girls had the same first name.
COOTIE makes another appearance.
Not that 9D clue is wrong, but what if they had referenced Kris  Kristofferson instead?  Too hard for a Tuesday?

Did not pick up on the fact that all the animals in the circles  were scavengers until I read the column.

Another nervous Tuesday.

Strands Thread.  Don't say any spoilers until after the View All Replies button please.  


Strands #324
“You don't say ...”
🔵🔵🔵🟡
🔵🔵🔵🔵

If I do say so myself, a cleverly titled puzzle from, I believe, a new constructor Monico Chavez.  (Apologies for the lack of diacriticals).

New to BRODOWN. Maybe derived from hoedown? Or...
Let's leave it a that!
Enjoy!

Solved in good time but made one error and I didn’t feel like scanning the puzzle to find it. Clever enough puzzle for a Tuesday, though more trivia/pop than I like to deal with slightly diminished it.
My 3-year streak was wiped out and my times are no longer recorded. How is this an improvement? (Rhetorical question)

The scavenger union has a long history of refusing to do hunters’ work, and its dues-paying members resent the continued use of the term “scavenger hunt” by the general public.

Other hurtful anti-scavenger terms in this puzzle:
STALK
EARN
KILT

Boy, I'm in a slump. Failed again, this time on a Tuesday. Had MCGEE, but MELC just looked awful. So I decided it must be MAGEE and MELA. Done in by Sporty Spice. 

The theme was simple and solid, and helped me with the unfamiliar LUISFONSI. BRODOWN was also unfamiliar, and I hope it will soon exit the language, along with the other BRO-words.

MELC still looks awful. Will need to do some reading now to relieve my ignorance of the name.

9 Down:
Kris Kristofferson wrote the song, not Janis.  Fred Foster is also credited on the album, but he had a habit of insinuating his name into the credits of many up-and-coming songwriters.

Loved this, not only for the two Spice Girls entries, but because it's the first NYT crossword that I've genuinely not had to look up one of the answers... yes, that included Monday crosswords as well. 

YOUHAVENOIDEA how relieved I am to hit this milestone. Thanks, Mr Caprera!!

I initially found the clue for 22A [Tool that may be used as a hoe] somewhat odd, as I have always thought of this implement as more of a wood-working tool. A quick check in Wiki confirms that it is in fact used in breaking up soil as well. Out of curiosity,  I looked at xword info to find that in its more than 100 appearances, it has virtually always been clued to coopers or woodworking. Once it was a [Hoelike cutting tool] and once a [Tool shed tool]. As Sam mentioned, it has even more often appeared as ADZe, but again virtually always clued to wood and cutting. TIL, there is a thing called a “mattock” which has an ADZ-like horizontal blade as well as a vertical pick-ax like blade. Then there is the “Pulaski”, which is the thing you see fire-fighters show up with, which has an Adz on one end and a real axe on the other. These last two have not appeared in puzzles yet to my knowledge.

A lot of proper nouns solved on the crosses today, but I'm embarrassed to say that MELB was a gimme. 
In contrast to many, SNARF is the version I'm familiar with---I've seen "scarf", but assumed it was a comic misprint.
No idea what a SCAVENGER HUNT is, or what it has to do with camping. Guessing it's a reference to American "summer camp"?

And, pace Joplin fans, "Me and Bobby McGee" is Kristofferson's. Always has been, always will be.

Cool theme. And I did, in fact, hunt for the scavengers after I finished. Made me smile.
Re: 33D, have we completely moved away from SCUBA being an acronym, and needing to be clued as an abbreviation? I'm okay with it - just checking.
And re: 55A...Zoom...omg...that's a thing?? TIL today.

Before you complain that something isn't a word,....

Would you just please Google it?

What?  No possum?  No raccoon?  No vulture, buzzard, or crow?  No ANTS?  Well, that might be too much of a crowd...

Ruth is labeled a GLEANER, but  ALL y'all know she was a SCAVENGER.  Fortunately, she caught the eye of Boaz.  I have always wondered if she dropped Naomi like a hot potato when he proposed.  

My main question as to do with the Spice Girls and Janis's Bobby:  did he spell it MAGEE or MCGEE?  Here we have a true Natick!
I guessed C.

AH YOU HAVE NO IDEA how little I know about the Spice Girls.

I also feel sorry for Michael CERA, evidently being known for a small role in "Barbie" (as evidenced by two very recent puzzle clues) instead of starring in some other great movies (e.g., "Scott Pilgrim vs. The World").

Still, very fun to hunt for those scavengers.

How on earth does one CLEAVE with an ox? Begin by cleaning your glasses.

Snowflakes here in Southern MS.

Thank you Dan

Was so taken aback that I didn't get the completion when I filled in the last square I physically leaned back. Eventually found SCARF hanging out at 1A trying not to draw attention to the CCO it implied.
SNARF did throw me off. I confidently had SCARF until I had to go searching for what I had wrong at the end. Should have paid more attention to the crossing!
Didn’t like this puzzle at all. I was never a fan of the Spice Girls. We’ll move on.
I was surprised that you were surprised at the word RV-ER. I've found that pretty commonly used on a lot of message board forums related to travel.

TIL that condors  don't kill for prey. That is super interesting to me. Last year my puppy killed a squirrel in the driveway, and I fretted over how to get rid of it.  But amazingly, I was outside and watched a hawk pick it up and fly off a little way with it. Also, I like the word "snarf," it is just fun to say.
Does anyone remember "snipe hunts" at scout camp?
It is great to see Will Shortz back in action as the editor. Joel Fagliano did a great job but there is no one like Will! Welome back Will!!!!!

RVER - there is a distinct difference between a camper (which is a trailer) and an RV, which is driven.

Easy - home on wheels resident
Medium - “On the Home”
Hard - Drives home

Cool theme, but too many clues unnecessarily repeated from recent puzzles. MAO ("Figure painted by Warhol") and CERA ("'Barbie' actor Michael") both appeared with almost exactly the same clues in the Sunday 1/19 puzzle just two days ago as "Iconic Warhol subject" and "Michael of 'Barbie'". Fine to repeat words, but different references would be nice. Plenty of options for those two.

Enjoyable puzzle! I’m not sure if anyone has observed, but today’s revealer is a quote from The LION King. When Simba tells his Uncle Scar that he’s weird, Scar (voiced by Jeremy Irons) replies “You have no idea.” This itself was an Easter egg harkening back to Jeremy Irons’ performance of Claus von Bulow in Reversal of Fortune and his reply when the Alan Dershowitz character tells him “You are a very strange man.”  Very clever!

I'm going to have to start Autochecking on Tuesdays instead of Wednesdays. The scavengers helped a lot, but even at my age (89 1/2 possibly "going on") I still didn't know "adze" doesn't require that "e." Among my several lookups, 36D HAD to be the BRODOWN that filled in from the crosses, but how could it be?

Among the things that show the cognitive stage I'm coming to, I needed crosses to get 66D. In my past I would have had that at sight on my first pass.
Do you know when the winners of the Mega will be listed?
Thanks for the Rummikub clue. That brought a flood of wonderful memories of family game time in the 1970's & 1980's.  You have made my heart so happy.
"Brodown"!?! This puzzle wasn't all that hard, but it was very, very lame.

Did the Spice Girls write their own songs? I'm guessing probably not, but maybe they contributed ideas. Note: I'm not pretending to be unfamiliar with their music. Despacito, on the other hand...

(Spoiler: The Ramones weren't actually related.)
Spent 80% of my time doing the crossword, and the other 20% not realising that it was supposed to be SNARF instead of scarf. Snarf? Is that even a word?
Much easier than Monday's puzzle, and because of that, more fun. Yesterday's was a slog.
I thought the clues were strange.

a lion is not a scavenger in any way whatsoever its a hunter.. a condor could be considered a scavenger but a crab? hyena is fair enough but crabs and lions are not scavengers wow ny times..

wow
Anyone else surprised by Zoom SEX? Scoured the comments and found nothing mentioning it (so far) I might be out of the loop!
Wow. My thoughts. BRO DOWN? Zoom SEX? ADZ(e)? Took grave liberties with this one, I'm afraid. Especially BRO DOWN--which I guess is a cutesy allusion to a hoedown. My thoughts? Wow.
I was hoping the answer to 22A would be "hoe".  Because a hoe is often used as a hoe.

Gotta say — the idea that i should be expected to know the difference between a CCO and an NCO on a tuesday, when both crosses work perfectly well, is a bit ridiculous. I thought that was one of the worst crosses in a long while, because it wasn't fun or interesting to figure it out, just aggravating.
What's the opposite of a BRODOWN ? A SISUP?

I enjoyed this theme and had an actual out-loud giggle when I got to put in bro down for 31d. However, I think snarf (1a) is criminal. Scarf makes so much more sense, and no one these days knows about military ranks, and why should I have to learn it now (2d)?
My last to solve was WMD; wasn't expecting and abbreviation, not from the clue. Still, a straightforward Tuesday puzzle.
Happy Birthday Baby Spice!

As many commenters have noticed/lamented (not in today's comments), the timer can be a bit wonky, often adding minutes or even *hours* to a solve time after you've finished a puzzle.

For this reason (and because I'm a math/numbers/excel geek), from this year I'm keeping a spreadsheet of my actual solve times.

Many commenters felt today's puzzle was rather difficult for a Tuesday. I'm not claiming otherwise, but of the three Tuesdays so far this year, it's my fastest, and less than half the time of January 7.
SNARF boo
SNARF was a crime. Otherwise a lovely Tuesday crossword, I must admit.
This is the second Tuesday in tßhe last 3 weeks which has not been a Tuesday puzzle. I feel like your quality control has slipped a lot. So much esoterica in this one....
Is a WOK really a stir fry "accessory" when it's.... The pan you use to make the stir fry?
Snarf really got me!! Why isn't it scarf??
@Cat Lady Margaret Thanks for the reminder! That was a fun reminder of standout puzzles from the last year, and it was surprising to me just how many of them I remembered right away. I voted! 🗳️
@Wayne Harrison that's true that everyone will have their own individuals experience, but this would be a situation where a sampling of subjective experiences is actually an objective measure
@Steven M. And Leon’s getting laaaarger…

@Steve L 
I always wondered why someone would want to drive a hotel room down a highway.

@Bruce 

Well, the obvious answer is that if you drive your hotel room down the highway, you don't need to pay for one when you get to your destination.  And of course, it's really a hotel suite, so you save on at least two hotel rooms.  Turtles don't pay rent.

Campsites, of course, usually charge for their use, but they are far less expensive, and some are even free.  You can even park in most Walmart lots overnight if you're between destinations.

You don't have to rely on restaurant food, which is much more expensive than making your own wherever you park, either outdoors on a fire, or in your own kitchen.

And unlike hotel rooms, when you're done using your RV, you can sell it and get at least some of the money you paid for it back.

And you need a vehicle to get to where you're going, anyway.  If you take an RV, you don't need a car.

Hope that clarifies things a bit.

@Bruce My experience with an RV was as transportation to and shelter at Burning Man for a few years in the early 2000s. I went in on the rental with a few friends and it made all the difference for me to be able to fully get into the experience right from the beginning, as I had never been camping before and the desert is a harsh place to live for a week. My last year I stayed in a tent next to the RV but still paid a portion of the rental for access to the bathroom. (:

I will say it was an odd experience sitting in the equivalent of a mini living room/kitchen while we were driving down the highway. But comfortable!

@Steve L 
When is the last time you paid for a campsite for a class A with full hookups?

@nash.mark 

Never, since mine was a Class C.  But when was the last time you paid for a luxury hotel suite?

@Bruce You wouldn't drive around NYC looking for a parking space, which would be near impossible because it's hard to find one that can hold one car. You'd need one three car lengths long. Here's your option: https://libertyharborrv.com/ Rates might seem high, but hotel rooms are much higher! PATH train or ferry to Manhattan. You can find a used RV under $20,000 easy. It just might not be luxurious or up-to-date. But a starter RV might be just the thing to get the feel for whether it's for you or not.

@Naud

Try MCGEE instead of Magee. MELA seems more likely than MELC. That was my problem anyway.

@SP 
That was one of my cheats.  Even my wiki cheat didn't help, as they listed Melanie C for Sporty Spice, and Mel B for Scary Spice.
@Naud Do you have SNARF or SCARF (my error) in 1A?
@Naud could it possibly be BECAME in the 2nd Spice Girls clue?
@Marshall Walthew I think about WHAM every December when I do some holiday shopping at the mall — in fact I just thought about them last Christmas!

@SP 
I thought it was a bit hard for a Tuesday, too.  But I'm sure most will love it.

@Joan 
Came say the same thing. And more than a few of us need a break today.

@SP 

I thought it was just me . Too many naticks. I had BECAME and AH for the longest time - don't know the song , and don't care to know it . Enough already .

@SP 

Yeah, about CLEAVE.  

Sily me, I thought it meant "to bind to," but my husband went with the meaning in today's puzzle.
He's my  EX.  
And I hear he stuck to that definition with the following two wives.  Not to be harsh, but that did make me smile.
@SP I think the back to back clues are intentional. I notice pairs like this all the time.
@SP MAO, CERA and KOI in multiple puzzles over the last week annoyed me. Seemingly more obscure but perhaps they’re becoming regulars like OREO and ERR?

@Bruce 
MEL(anie) C as opposed to 
MEL B
Tell me what you want. What you really, really want.

@Bruce 
Apparently, there were two Spice Girls whose given names were “Melanie,” so the particular member from the clue went by “MEL C” in addition to her other stage name. The ‘C’ is short for her surname, “Chisholm.”

@Stephen

Thanks for ending my miserable hunt for the wrong square. I was also stuck on CCO instead of NCO. SNARF never even occurred to me!
@Naud count me as another person stumped by ScARF/cCO!

@Stephen I went through & checked all my acrosses & downs 3 times before giving up & checking puzzle to reveal the incorrect C for N. CCO was a military acronym when I googled it, so it never occurred to me that SCARF was incorrect!

Everyone on this thread:
"Drop and give me ten."
@Stephen ditto

@Striker
To me, SNARFing is the act of inhaling a chunk of Jello into the back of your throat so that you don't have to swallow it. Think "Jello shots" in college years.

@nash.mark 
Excellent description, except I think you meant "you don't have to *chew* it," right?

@Pani Korunova 

Repeats of recent clues and answers are a gift to regular solvers. Lagniappe! Like frequent flyer miles.
Enjoy them.

Not sure if you missed much on the Spice Girls, I don't know much about them either. They were a huge pop phenomenon, especially in England, so they are prime  puzzle fodder. With crossword-friendly names, short with common letters.

@Justin 
Nice!

@Dee

Haven’t lived here very long.  I just learned something new! Noticed they have 3 locations! Thanks for the tip! 😉

@Justin

They recently opened a location on Belleview. Haven’t tried it yet but I can literally walk over in less than a minute! Thanks for the recommendation! 😉

Jean F,

And again just now.
“The Wave” meets the butterfly effect?
:)

@Vaer that was an incredibly moving article. Thank you for sharing it.

a regular!

The term derives from the Ancient Greek διακριτικός (diakritikós, "distinguishing"), from διακρίνω (diakrínō, "to distinguish"). The word diacritic is a noun, though it is sometimes used in an attributive sense, whereas diacritical is only an adjective.

@Once a Marine 
Snipe hunts, absolutely!
Andrzej, Nothing of the sort. Summer (not scout) camp for me. It's been around for quite a while. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snipe_hunt

@Andrzej Thankfully, it’s just a (usually harmless) prank. New campers are told that there’s an animal called a snipe in the woods and are sent out to find it. In fact, there is no animal called a snipe (well—there is, it’s a bird, but never mind that), so typically the snipe hunter just wanders around in the woods getting mildly lost and majorly frustrated!

@CaptainQuahog 
Not to mention The Hunting of the Snark, by Lewis Carroll. (Portmanteau of snake and shark.)  A Snipe is also a small sailboat, like a Sunfish, but with a jib and a main sail. (My dad had a Widgeon.)

@Once a Marine 

After the Snipe Hunt we sent the Tenderfeet out to find the left handed smoke shifter.

@John Carson My father's version from his scouting days was  either a left-handed monkey wrench or the key to the flagpole.
Thanks for the memories of enjoying his memories.

@Ken Burk Camper is a general term for vehicles such as self-contained RVs and trailers. All RVs are campers. I think the distinction you're trying to point out is simply between RVs and trailers, although trailers--non-motorized elements that are towed--are sometimes also considered RVs. https://koa.com/blog/the-beginners-guide-to-buying-an-rv-what-exactly-is-an-rv/ (I think the KOA people know what they're talking about.) Campers can be either motorized RVs or trailers: https://merriam-webster.com/dictionary/camper https://britannica.com/dictionary/camper When you search "camper definition" for images, you get: https://tinyurl.com/yvhrss9r Hope this helps!

@acjones "The lion eats anything it can catch and kill, but it depends mostly on animals weighing 50 - 300 kg. Up to 40 kg of meat can be consumed by an adult male at one meal. Lions are also expert scavengers and obtain as much as 40% of their food by stealing it from other predators, or finding already dead animals. For many old males, too old to catch live game, scavenging may be their only way to find food. " https://torontozoo.com/animals/African%20lion#:~:text=The%20lion%20eats%20anything%20it,or%20finding%20already%20dead%20animals. " Crabs are scavengers, eating everything from fish, oysters, clams, snails, shrimp, and worms to other crabs. Blue crabs use underwater grasses for shelter from predators and a place to feed on small invertebrates and plant matter." https://cbf.org/document-library/education-resources/blue-crab-101-investigation.pdf

@acjones - Lions most certainly are often scavengers. Most crabs are also, almost exclusively, scavengers. 

Many of what be consider big, dangerous predators get a significant amount, of their sustenance from scavenging.
